coin flips and dice rolls are only independent if you use a different coin/die every time. If a die or coin is weighted to favour particular results, then you should expect the chance of getting the same outcome again to be larger, and after every flip/roll you can update your expectations based on the previous results, and the more results you've seen, the more accurate your expectations tend to be.
No coin/die is perfect, so even if it's not purposely weighted, it might have an accidental bias to a certain result, and if you keep using the same coin/die, then it would be more sensible to expect results in line with prior results than to expect results differing from prior results.

Finally, I GET IT!

Thank you

From bayes rule, Most important use is to calculate Probability of Cause given Effect
P(cause|effect) = P(effect|cause)*P(cause)/P(effect)
Since most of the scenarios in any experiment or simulation ,its easy to get value of effect by applying cause ,i.e P(effect|cause) can be easily calculated by actual experiment
Now using Bayes theorm one can calculate P(cause|effect)


An example
Question:You are working on your laptop, and you hear a whirring noise from it, whenever you boot it. You go to a technician and he tells you that 80% of the cases of laptop repair that come to him, have the same problem of whirring noise. You assume that the issue is from your hard-drive, and you read online that 20% of all laptop issues are hard-drive related, while the problem of getting a whirring noise from the laptop on boot from a hard-drive related issue is 50%. Given this information, you calculate the probability that you have a hard-drive related issue in your laptop ?
Answer:This is a simple application of bayes rule.
Here whirring noise is an “Effect” or symptom,and Hard-Drive related issues serve as a probable “Cause”. Then P(cause) = 20% and P(effect) = 80%, and P(effect|cause) = 50%. From bayes rule,
P(cause|effect) =
P(effect|cause)*P(cause)/P(effect) = 0.5*0.2/0.8 = ⅛

With a square or circle of area 1, while the area represents probability.
Then we cut the square or circle with two straight lines to divide the shape into 4 areas: P(H && E), P(E && !H), P(H && !E), P(!E && !H).
Given their proportions, return the coordinates of the vertices of the cutting edges.

"Theorem" is a big word for this easy one step conclusion of the definition. The reason is the commutivity of the intersection. The video gives a wrong impression: We are speaking about the probability of the intersection of two sets and not about the probability of an "and assertion". In fact the probability theory is very missleading. Sometimes you form the probability of sets and sometimes the probability of assertions. Yes there is a straight connection between the assertion of membership and the fact to be a member. But it is not the same. Probability theory is not consistent. P(A|B) is the probability of an assertion (conditioned probability). P(A) and P(A intersects B) are probabilities of sets. The latter are consistent with set theory. Because the intersection is commutative the same intersection can be part of two different conditional probabilities around A and B. You get the identity in only one step. It is completely oversized to make an own "theorem" of this simple conclusion. It complicates instead of simplifiing. A theorem should assemble many steps. BTW: P(A|B) should not be regarded as a probability but as a constant describing the ratio of the the intersecting part with one of the intersecting partners. This would clarify the essence much more. It is clear that such a ratio can always be interpreted as a probability of a partial set. But this doesn't help to the understanding in this case.

It's worth emphasizing the last point brought up - let's say the chances for you to contract disease X are 1%. You go to a doctor and do a test, which is 99.9% percent likely to correctly identify that you are infected, and only 10% likely to incorrectly conclude that you are infected even though you're not.
If so, you can conclude that the odds of you getting a positive result back regardless of whether you're infected or not are: P(Correct diagnosis)*P(You are infected)+P(Incorrect worry)*P(You are not infected), which equals 0.999*0.01+0.1*0.99=0.10899

Then, according to Bayes' theorem, if the test came back positive, the actual chance that you really are affect by disease X is: P(You are infected)*P(Correct diagnosis)/P(Positive test result) = 0.01*0.999/0.10899 = only 9.17%. In other words, even if the test results came back positive, you STILL shouldn't be so worried, as you only have a 9.17% chance of actually having disease X. This is 9 times higher than the average, but it's still not even close to the 99.9% chance you may expect.
This is because disease X is just that rare, and thus many healthy people come to the clinic and test negative. Now you have to ask yourself - how much of a tendency to be infected with disease X do people who go and test for disease X have? It's likely higher than the general 1% chance...
This effect is called false positives vs false negatives. It's very important in medical studies.

P(B|A) = P(A&B)/P(A) is the only part of Bayes's theorem I do remember, and I remember it as a picture (draw a Venn diagram for A and B, then realize that if A is true, what's outside the A bubble doesn't matter, and you need to re-normalize probabilities so in the post-learning-A-is-true world probabilities still add up to 1). Then I reconstruct the formula if I need it. But I can actually often just apply that "proto-Bayes formula" directly.

For me, it’s more natural to think of Bayes’ theorem as the implicit definition of “given” in probability, ie “given” (vertical bar | ) just means whatever makes the following a valid axiom of probability theory:

P(A) * P(B|A) = P(B) * P(A|B)

I mean, words like “and” are kind of vaguely defined. You can define

A&B = “A and B|A”

But then you have to add the assumption that A&B = B&A, which is obvious to our minds but certainly not obvious from the algebra alone.

I agree this video is a valid proof of the theorem, but only but relying on an assumption about commutatively and the definition of “and”. Everyone would agree with “and” being commutative, but I don’t see that it’s obviously true that “and” should be defined as “A * B|A”. You can have this as an axiom but then you might as well just start with Bayes’ theorem as an axiom to start with.

You might think that this is just some mathematical issue, but the point made at 1:52 can have dramatic consequences. An English solicitor Sally Clark was convicted of killing her two baby sons on this same statistical error given as "evidence" by an eminent doctor (not statistician) and jailed. She served three years of a longer sentence before the Royal College of Statisticians intervened to point out the error of multiplying the probability of two children dying of the same cause, which was sudden infant death syndrome, and more likely to be genetic and in both children. Her career destroyed, she died from alcohol intoxication (suicide?) and the "eminent" doctor was struck off the medical registration list.

I've always found it strange that this is even called a theorem. You literally have by definition that P(A|B)P(B)=P(A and B), from which it almost directly follows. I think it should have been called Bayes' formula.

In the example given at 2:21, I noticed that the animation shows an increase in probability only horizontally, i.e. that your brother dying of heart disease means you are more likely to die of heart disease. Does it not also hold that if you die, of heart disease, your brother is then more likely to die of heart disease, implying a stretch not only horizontally but also vertically? If my thinking is incorrect, I'm very interested as to why.

Personally I like to think of it from a set theory perspective where P means proportion. You have some set of all the possibilities T and in this context, for some sets A,B of T: P(A|B)=#(A and B)/#B.
This is the proportion of elements of B that are also in A or in other words the proportion of times A happenned of the times B has allready happenned.


Here P(A)=P(A|T)=#(A and T)/#T=#A/#T
using this, Bayes' theorem is quite obvious.
